title: Derek Birnage
text:
Derek Arthur William Birnage (13 June 1913 – 18 January 2004) was a British comics editor and writer and newspaper editor, best known as the founding editor of the weekly sports comic "<a href="Tiger%20%28Fleetway%29">Tiger</a>" and as a writer of "<a href="Roy%20of%20the%20Rovers">Roy of the Rovers</a>".
He was born in <a href="Wandsworth">Wandsworth</a>, South <a href="London">London</a>, on 13 June 1913, the son of Frank Birnage, editor of the conservative evangelical newspaper the "<a href="Sunday%20Companion">Sunday Companion</a>", and was educated at <a href="Sutton%20Valence%20School">Sutton Valence School</a> in <a href="Kent">Kent</a>. After leaving school he joined the comics department of <a href="Amalgamated%20Press">Amalgamated Press</a> under <a href="Reg%20Eves">Reg Eves</a>, initially working on "<a href="Schooldays%20%28comic%29">Schooldays</a>". After it folded he moved to "<a href="The%20Champion%20%28comics%29">The Champion</a>" as a sub-editor under <a href="Bernard%20Smith%20%28comics%20editor%29">Bernard Smith</a>, also writing "Colwyn Dane", a detective strip, for the title.
During the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a> he did his military service in the <a href="Royal%20Signal%20Corps">Royal Signal Corps</a>, before acting as editor of "The Champion" until Smith returned. He then left to write children's stories for rival publisher <a href="Amex%20%28publisher%29">Amex</a>, but quit after only four months to run a toy shop in <a href="Bexhill-on-Sea">Bexhill</a> with his wife, Audrey Waterman, whom he had married in 1946, and her parents. When Audrey's mother died a few years later, the shop was sold, and Birnage returned to Amalgamated Press. In 1952 he became editor of "The Champion" while Smith launched a new title, "<a href="Lion%20%28comics%29">Lion</a>".
In 1954 Birnage launched a new sports-themed comic, "<a href="Tiger%20%28comic%29">Tiger</a>", and asked writer <a href="Frank%20S.%20Pepper">Frank S. Pepper</a> to create a more realistic <a href="Association%20football">football</a> strip than "The Champion"'s "Danny of the Dazzlers". The result was "<a href="Roy%20of%20the%20Rovers">Roy of the Rovers</a>", drawn by <a href="Joe%20Colquhoun">Joe Colquhoun</a>, who later also wrote the strip under the pseudonym Stewart Colwyn. After Colquhoun left in 1959, Birnage wrote the strip himself, using the pseudonym Frank Winsor, when not ghost-writing for the credited writer, <a href="Bobby%20Charlton">Bobby Charlton</a>.
Birnage left "Tiger", and "Roy of the Rovers", in 1963, to edit comics annuals. He left comics in 1964 to edit his father's old paper, the "<a href="Sunday%20Companion">Sunday Companion</a>", until it closed in 1970, before returning to <a href="IPC%20Media">IPC</a> (as the publisher was now called after a series of mergers) to work for a new football comic, "<a href="Score%20%27n%27%20Roar">Score 'n' Roar</a>", under <a href="Sid%20Bicknell">Sid Bicknell</a>. He also edited "<a href="Smash%21%20%28comics%29">Smash!</a>" and "<a href="Buster%20%28comics%29">Buster</a>" before he was made redundant in 1972.
After jobs in publishing, planning, and the <a href="Department%20of%20Health%20and%20Social%20Security">Department of Health and Social Security</a>, Birnage retired to <a href="Burgess%20Hill">Burgess Hill</a>, <a href="West%20Sussex">West Sussex</a>, where he died on 18 January 2004, survived by his wife and their three children.
